Our 6th grade students have been studying water ecology in science this year. They visited Brooklyn Bridge Park and The River Project at Pier 40 to test water quality and learn about the ecosystem surrounding our neighborhood waterways. Students have learned about the effects of pollution from four different land uses (agricultural, industrial, commercial and residential) on our local water by testing salinity, turbidity, and Ph.

The stream tables ask students to bring all of their learning together by choosing two different land uses and building a model showing characteristics of each. Then they will run water through the table to see how erosion and deposition interact with pollution and change the health of the water.

Professionally used by scientists, stream tables paint a remarkably accurate picture to observe and analyze.

Our middle schoolers took to the courts starting with the nuts and bolts of the federal government. Using school desegregation then and now as a lens, they explored the ways in which the federal government impacts us, and how we can be an influence. Continuing on to the judicial branch the students learned about their rights and responsibilities under the U.S. Constitution.

Today's mock trial was a culmination of a three month government study and explored the tension between free speech and the safety of our communities. Drawing on legal precedence from landmark Supreme Court cases, our students argued their cases in court. Our justices applied their understanding of the case law, as well as the validity of the arguments made that day, to come to their decision.

What is it about Community Roots’ school culture that makes students feel they are safe, respected, and accountable for themselves as responsible community members?

Teachers at Community Roots support daily interactions between students and teachers that create and reinforce a powerful sense of school community. This culture feels most poignant when conflicts arise—and conflict at Community Roots is framed as an essential part of the learning process. Community Roots teachers empower students as active participants in solving problems. Students at Community Roots learn how to be confident, independent, and responsible problem solvers and community members.

To learn more about Community Roots’ strong classroom culture, join us at our annual event on April 25th (www.communityroots.org/gala) or call or email us to set up a time to visit: (718) 858-1629 or info@communityroots.org.

Building community at Community Roots Charter School is a daily practice. Twice a year, this takes on special meaning through Community Open Work (COW). Through COW, family members collaborate with teachers to offer an array of six-week, multi-age workshops on a wide range of topics from Woodworking to Origami, to Community Cooking.

The purpose of COW is to nurture relationships between students and teachers on different grade levels, family members, and staff, and, ultimately, create a community where everyone feels purposeful, inspired, and valued.

A couple of quotes from parents and staff members about COW:

"This is the highlight of their week"--of students' high level of energy and self-direction during COW.

"(It is exciting to)...watch students actually be able to build something with their hands." This focus on learning by doing is a central piece of a Community Roots' education.

If you are interested in learning more about COW (or setting up a time to visit), contact at us info@communityroots.org.

In a discussion with Community Roots parents today, two students were described:

One student was a talkative child who had received negative consequences (at a previous school) for his active personality--at Community Roots, teachers understood and accepted this student for who he was, worked to make him feel comfortable, and supported him to become a successful participant in the classroom community.

A second student entered Community Roots as a shy child, who was often reluctant to speak up--this parent described how Community Roots teachers helped her come out of her shell, taught her to stand up for what she thinks, and, in short, supported her to become "fearless".

Bottom Line: Community Roots Teachers meet the different needs of each and every student--and inspire students' confidence and independence!
